description: NASA Small Business Innovation Research Phase I

technical_abstract.name: Technical Abstract
technical_abstract.guidelines: Write a concise technical abstract (200-400 words) summarizing the innovation, anticipated results, and potential NASA applications. Focus on how this addresses specific NASA mission needs.
technical_abstract.description: Technical summary for NASA reviewers and program managers

innovation_and_technical_approach.name: Innovation and Technical Approach
innovation_and_technical_approach.guidelines: Describe the innovation and its significance to NASA. Explain the technical approach, methodology, and how it advances state-of-the-art. Address technical feasibility, TRL advancement (typically 2 to 4), and how Phase I will demonstrate proof-of-concept. Include discussion of technical risks and mitigation.

anticipated_benefits.name: Anticipated Benefits
anticipated_benefits.guidelines: Describe specific benefits to NASA missions and programs. Address both near-term and long-term applications. Include potential spinoff applications for other government agencies and commercial markets. Be specific about which NASA centers, directorates, or missions would benefit.
anticipated_benefits.description: Benefits to NASA and potential applications

work_plan.name: Work Plan
work_plan.guidelines: Provide detailed 6-month work plan with monthly tasks, milestones, and deliverables. Include Gantt chart or timeline. Show technical performance metrics and success criteria for each milestone. Identify go/no-go decision points. Plan must be realistic for 6 months and $150K.
work_plan.description: Detailed schedule with milestones and metrics

related_research.name: Related Research
related_research.guidelines: Summarize relevant prior research by the proposing team and others. Cite key publications and patents. Explain how this work differs from and builds upon prior art. Demonstrate understanding of current state-of-the-art in the field.
related_research.description: Review of related work and prior art

commercialization_strategy.name: Commercialization Strategy
commercialization_strategy.guidelines: Describe the commercialization strategy including NASA and non-NASA markets. Identify potential NASA customers, other government agencies, and commercial applications. Explain path to Phase II and beyond. Include discussion of IP strategy and competitive advantages.

facilities_and_equipment.name: Facilities and Equipment
facilities_and_equipment.guidelines: Describe available facilities, equipment, and resources. Identify any unique capabilities. Explain how facilities are adequate for proposed Phase I work. Include any university, NASA center, or other partnerships.
facilities_and_equipment.description: Description of available facilities and resources

key_personnel.name: Key Personnel and Qualifications
key_personnel.guidelines: Provide biographical sketches for Principal Investigator and key personnel (1 page max per person). Include education, relevant experience, publications, and role in the project. Demonstrate team's capability to successfully execute Phase I.

budget_narrative.name: Budget Narrative and Justification
budget_narrative.guidelines: Provide detailed budget up to $150,000 for 6-month Phase I. Break down by: Direct Labor (by person with rates), Fringe Benefits, Materials and Supplies, Equipment, Travel, Consultants/Subcontractors, Other Direct Costs, Indirect Costs. Justify each item and show calculations. Budget must align with work plan.

technical_merit.description: Scientific and technical merit of the innovation
sub_criteria: Degree of innovation and technical merit
Soundness of technical approach and methodology
Qualifications of Principal Investigator and team
Adequacy of resources and facilities
Realism of cost and schedule

nasa_relevance.description: Relevance to NASA mission and needs
sub_criteria: Relevance to NASA mission objectives and needs
Potential contribution to NASA programs and missions
TRL advancement appropriate for Phase I
Feasibility of achieving stated Phase I objectives
Clear path to Phase II development
Potential for commercial application and success
Size and accessibility of market
Company's ability to commercialize
Dual-use potential (NASA and commercial)
Intellectual property strategy
Company's relevant experience and past performance
Track record with NASA or other government agencies
Quality of facilities and resources
Team stability and commitment
Prior SBIR/STTR success if applicable

format_specifications.font: Times New Roman, Palatino, or Computer Modern

special_requirements.u.s._citizen_pi: Not required, but work must be performed in U.S.
special_requirements.small_business_majority: Small business must perform >50% of work
special_requirements.technology_taxonomy: Must align with NASA Technology Taxonomy

trl_definitions.TRL_3: Analytical and experimental critical function and/or proof of concept
trl_definitions.TRL_4: Component and/or breadboard validation in laboratory environment
trl_definitions.TRL_5: Component and/or breadboard validation in relevant environment
trl_definitions.TRL_6: System/subsystem model or prototype demonstration in relevant environment
